title: 114_hr3286
content: The Act is known as the "Honoring Investments in Recruiting and Employing American Military Veterans Act of 2016" or the "HIRE Vets Act". It establishes the HIRE VETS Medallion Program. The HIRE Vets Act establishes a HIRE Vets Medallion Program to recognize employers' efforts in recruiting, employing, and retaining veterans, as well as providing community services. The Secretary of Labor will establish the program and accept voluntary applications from employers for consideration of receiving a HIRE Vets Medallion. The HIRE Vets Act establishes a program to recognize employers for hiring veterans. The Secretary of Labor reviews applications and provides a list of recipients to the President. The President notifies recipients of their awards and announces their names on Veterans Day, issuing them a HIRE Vets Medallion and a certificate. The HIRE Vets Act allows employers to display a HIRE Vets Medallion the following year. The Secretary solicits applications by January 31st, stops accepting them by April 30th, and finishes reviewing by August 31st each year. Employers must submit applications by August 31st each year for HIRE Vets Medallions to be awarded in November. The Secretary recommends recipients to the President by September 30th, and the President notifies awardees by October 11th. SEC. 3. SELECTION OF RECIPIENTS. The Secretary reviews all applications to determine if an employer qualifies for a HIRE Vets Medallion based on their programs and efforts from the previous year. Verification of information provided is conducted to assess eligibility. The Secretary establishes two levels of HIRE Vets Medallions for large employers with 500 or more employees: the Gold HIRE Vets Medallion and the Platinum HIRE Vets Medallion. To qualify for a Gold HIRE Vets Medallion, an employer must have hired veterans constituting at least 7 percent of all employees in the previous calendar year. To be eligible for a Platinum HIRE Vets Medallion, an employer must have veterans make up at least 10 percent of all employees hired in the previous calendar year. Additionally, the employer must have established an employee veteran organization or resource group to assist new veteran employees with integration, and programs to enhance the leadership skills of veteran employees during their employment. To be eligible for a Platinum HIRE Vets Medallion, an employer must retain at least 85 percent of veteran employees hired in the previous calendar year and provide compensation to employees serving in the National Guard or Reserve. The employer must also have dedicated human resources professionals to support veteran hiring and training efforts. The employer must provide active duty pay to maintain the employee's salary level and offer a tuition assistance program for veteran employees. Smaller employers with 5,000 or fewer employees must have at least one HR professional supporting veteran hiring efforts. The Secretary may establish additional criteria for HIRE Vets Medallion qualifications. Awards will be given to small- and medium-sized employers based on their support for veterans. The Secretary will also determine the design of the medallion. The HIRE Vets Medallion qualifications may have additional criteria established by the Secretary. Awards will be given to small- and medium-sized employers based on their support for veterans. The design of the medallion will be determined by the Secretary. The recipient of a HIRE Vets Medallion can publicly display the medallion and certificate. It is illegal for an employer to falsely display the medallion in any advertisement or business activity. Employers are prohibited from falsely implying they received the HIRE Vets Medallion during the previous calendar year. SEC. 5. APPLICATION FEE AND FUNDING. A fund called the "HIRE Vets Medallion Award Fund" is established in the Treasury. Employers applying for the HIRE Vets Medallion may be charged a fee, which will be deposited into the Fund to cover program costs. The Fund will be used by the Secretary for the HIRE Vets Medallion Program. SEC. 6. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary must submit annual reports to Congress on fees collected from HIRE Vets Medallion applicants, program administration costs, number of applications received, and medallions awarded, including employer names and medallion levels. The reports will be provided to specific committees. The Secretary must submit annual reports to specific committees in Congress on fees collected from HIRE Vets Medallion applicants, program administration costs, number of applications received, and medallions awarded, including employer names and medallion levels. These committees include the Committees on Education and the Workforce, Veterans' Affairs of the House of Representatives, and the Committees on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions, Veterans' Affairs of the Senate. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "employer," "Secretary," and "veteran" in relation to their meanings under specific sections of the United States Code. The term "employer" excludes the Federal Government, States, and foreign states. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Labor. The term "veteran" is defined as per section 101 of title 38, United States Code.
